item.title: Sarah Everard case: Met police faces watchdog investigation
item.description: The police watchdog will examine the force's handling of an earlier indecent exposure allegation against the officer suspected of murdering her.

item.title: Lockdown in Wales: Hairdressers to reopen but retail remains closed
item.description: People will soon be able meet friends in their garden, visit care homes inside and play golf.

item.title: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe needs mental health treatment, charity says
item.description: The British-Iranian woman faces a new court hearing this weekend, following a five-year sentence.

item.title: Cumbria coal mine: 'Increased controversy' prompts public inquiry
item.description: Ministers were warned the proposal is damaging the UK's reputation ahead of a major climate summit.

item.title: Car insurance claims plunge as drivers stay at home
item.description: The drop in claims is not mirrored in cheaper premiums, but insurers say motorists have been supported.

item.title: Twins peak with more born than ever before
item.description: One in every 42 children is born a twin and much has changed over the past 30 years, a report finds.

item.title: Covid pandemic: Biden eyes 4 July as ‘Independence Day’ from virus
item.description: The US president says he is boosting efforts to vaccinate Americans in his first prime-time speech.

item.title: Royal Mail to pilot Sunday parcel delivery
item.description: The postal service will make deliveries for major retailers as online shopping continues to grow.

item.title: Running from terror in north-east Mozambique
item.description: A militant Islamist insurgency in north-east Mozambique has forced half a million people to flee for fear of beheadings and abductions.

item.title: Meghan and Harry interview: Royal Family 'very much not racist' - William
item.description: The Duke of Cambridge says he has yet to speak to his brother Prince Harry following the Oprah interview.

item.title: Turing Scheme: What is the Erasmus replacement?
item.description: What will Brexit mean for students in the UK wanting to work or study abroad?

item.title: Brown stink bug among 'future threats' to gardens
item.description: Gardeners are being urged to be on alert for the stink bug and other pests predicted to arrive in the UK.

item.title: BBC announces new Bitesize learning plans
item.description: The new programmes will help support both pupils and teachers across the UK.

item.title: The papers: Met faces Sarah case inquiry and William hits back
item.description: The Sarah Everard case and Prince William's response to the Sussexes' interview dominate the papers.

item.title: Meghan Markle interview: African-American women react
item.description: Many African-American women were delighted when one of their own married a real prince - but times have changed.

item.title: A yak herder in the Himalayas: ‘I am the last shepherd in my family’
item.description: Phuntsog Tsering lives a tough life, herding yaks at 5,000m in the Himalayas and is one of the last shepherds left in his village.

item.title: Musicians in lockdown: 'My piano kept me going'
item.description: A series of portraits aims to show the impact of the pandemic on musicians' livelihoods.

item.title: 'Puppy scammers left me heartbroken'
item.description: More than 6,000 people in the UK have been victims of pet scammers since the first lockdown a year ago.

item.title: The digital artist who just netted a cool £50m
item.description: The digital-only artist is now among the top three most valuable living artists.

item.title: Eurovision 2021: James Newman reveals Embers as UK song
item.description: The singer will take 'fun and upbeat' track Embers to the Eurovision Song Contest in Rotterdam.

item.title: Sinkholes appearing in Croatian village after earthquake
item.description: They've been appearing in unusually high numbers after an earthquake hit the region in December.

item.title: The Hebrides' wild swimming 'real-life' mermaid
item.description: Kate MacLeod can be found swimming in seas and lochs around the Western Isles in summer - and winter.

item.title: Catcalling: The sisters who are making a noise to stop street harassment of women
item.description: Campaigners tell the BBC how they are working to address the root causes of violence against women.

item.title: The Scottish mercenary hired to kill Pablo Escobar
item.description: How a team of British combatants travelled to Colombia to assassinate the world's most dangerous man.

item.title: 'I play digital music through my 1949 radio'
item.description: People share some of their collections of vintage technology and explain why it is still useful.

item.title: Covid: Does Tanzania have a hidden epidemic?
item.description: The Tanzanian authorities have not published data on coronavirus infections or deaths for many months.

item.title: Top Gear trio on James Bond, mid-life crises and UK-only trips
item.description: The BBC One series is returning with James Bond cars, mid-life crises and all-British locations.

item.title: Kathleen Folbigg: Could science free Australian jailed for killing babies?
item.description: Kathleen Folbigg has been called Australia's worst female murderer - now scientists doubt her guilt.

item.title: China's parliament remakes Hong Kong in its own image
item.description: "One Country, Two Systems" was an experiment centred on the defining ideological divide of our time.

item.title: Virtual reality headsets for work ‘could snowball’
item.description: Use of the headsets by people working from home could pick up quite rapidly, a business group says.

item.title: Covid: Are Texas and Mississippi lifting restrictions too soon?
item.description: Two US states are lifting compulsory coronavirus restrictions, but are they in a position to do so?

item.title: Teenage suicide: Bereaved siblings fight mental health 'stigma'
item.description: Three young people who lost their siblings to suicide are urging distressed teenagers to seek help.

item.title: 'He does everything' - Kane double sees Spurs put one foot in quarter-finals
item.description: Harry Kane scores twice as Tottenham put one foot in the Europa League quarter-finals with a clinical win against Dinamo Zagreb.

item.title: Arteta says Arsenal are their own worst enemy after Olympiakos win
item.description: Martin Odegaard sets Arsenal on their way to a commanding first-leg lead over Olympiakos in their Europa League last-16 tie.

item.title: Late AC Milan equaliser denies Man Utd win after Diallo's first goal
item.description: AC Milan score a late equaliser to cancel out Amad Diallo's first Manchester United goal in the first leg of their Europa League last-16 tie.

item.title: Rangers recover to earn valuable draw at Slavia Prague
item.description: Rangers recover from an early setback to earn a creditable away draw in the first leg of their Europa League last-16 tie against Slavia Prague.

item.title: 'Excitement of T20 series is enough to pause rotation debate'
item.description: There are parts of England's rotation policy that are understandable and the action in the T20 series against India will be enough to pause the debate.

item.title: Nightmare start for McIlroy as Garcia takes Players Championship lead
item.description: Rory McIlroy makes a disappointing start to the defence of his title at the Players Championship as he slumped to a seven-over 79 at TPC Sawgrass.

item.title: Referee Drysdale given backdated ban for Judge clash
item.description: Darren Drysdale is free to officiate again after being given a backdated suspension for improper conduct.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: England has entered the first stage of its lockdown easing with millions of children back at school.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 23 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: What are the new rules for schools?
item.description: All students in England can now return to classrooms, but how will Covid testing work?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: The government says it may still be too early to book summer holidays abroad.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of new variants of Covid-19.

item.title: What are the Brazil, South Africa and UK variants and will vaccines work?
item.description: More cases are being found in the UK, including a variant first seen in Brazil.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased in England. When will services like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the test-and-trace system work?
item.description: MPs have said the government's test-and-trace system is too expensive and hasn't helped fight the pandemic.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK. So when might you get one?

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Coronavirus testing: How to do a lateral flow test at home
item.description: Coronavirus lateral flow tests are free and provide a quick result within 30 minutes. But how do you do one?

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the care home visiting rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: How could children make up for lost school time?
item.description: A massive task lies ahead for schools as they try to make up for teaching time lost during the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus, schools and children - what are the risks?
item.description: How much do children contribute to the spread of Covid?

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Abducted, shackled and forced to marry at 12
item.description: Up to 1,000 Christian, Hindu and Sikh girls are abducted in Pakistan every year, then forced to convert to Islam, and to marry.
